docs.lead_paragraph: It was the Al and Rob show, an unlikely new comedy duo now making occasional appearances on the campaign trail to the White House. Starring Vice President Al Gore, a politician with a famously wooden public demeanor, and Rob Reiner, the actor and director known for sly satire, the team came to the Rainbow Babies and Children's Hospital here to talk about the serious subject of children without medical insurance. But as the two stood side by side in the hospital atrium, swapping turns with the microphone in a discussion with doctors and parents, the topic was at times overtaken by two other objectives of the Gore campaign: making Mr. Gore more likable, and finding ways to attack George W. Bush without turning voters off.

headline.main: Touch of Comedy on Campaign Trail

docs.abstract: Democratic presidential candidate Vice Pres Al Gore and actor/director Rob Reiner visit Rainbow Babies and Children's Hospital in Cleveland, where they discuss serious topic of children without health insurance; engage in humorous repartee--welcome surprise to many Gore aides and friends, frustrated by his inability to project lightness of being that seems to come easily for adversary, Gov George W Bush; photo (M)
docs.snippet: It was the Al and Rob show, an unlikely new comedy duo now making occasional appearances on the campaign trail to the White House. Starring Vice President Al Gore, a politician with a famously wooden public demeanor, and Rob Reiner, the actor and...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Convention will adopt a platform on Tuesday that, like its Republican counterpart, makes a broad effort to reach voters in the middle, calling for schools to be more accountable for student performance, stricter control of the nation's borders, expanded global trade, a stronger military and the death penalty. But in the details, the platforms sharply diverge on most issues, providing clear indications of how Gore and Bush administrations would differ.

headline.main: Democrats Ready the Stage For Their Post-Clinton Era

docs.abstract: Democratic National Convention will adopt platform that like Republican counterpart makes broad effort to reach voters in middle but sharply diverges on most issues, providing clear indications on how Gore and Bush administrations will differ; plaftorms are alike, despite clear disagreements, in that they closely reflect styles, broad visions and campaign agendas of both candidates; compared (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Holly E. Cain, manager of the local welfare office, used to post job openings for welfare recipients just inside the front door of her agency here. She nearly put herself out of business. Welfare disappeared from this county. For more than a year, there have been no new cases, no old cases, no one on the rolls receiving cash assistance. Mrs. Cain still clips and posts help-wanted advertisements from local merchants, schools and hospitals. But the notices are no longer intended for welfare recipients. All sorts of people stop by to check what jobs might be available.

headline.main: How an Illinois County Cleared the Welfare Rolls

docs.abstract: Schuyler County, Ill, is first county in state and one of first in nation to be 'welfare-free,' illustrating in microcosm some of profound changes that have transformed much of nation's welfare system since Pres Clinton signed landmark welfare-reform law in 1996; county's elimination of cash assistance resulted not just from strong economy, but from hard work by local welfare officials, who gave much personal attention to each case and became adept at matching welfare recipients with jo

docs.lead_paragraph: The Democratic convention starting on Monday in Los Angeles will be a display of wealth, power and influence as gaudy as the Republican show in Philadelphia. Giving some of the most lavish parties will be Hollywood movie moguls, important Democratic sponsors at a time when the Democratic National Committee remains heavily dependent on its triad of financial support: trial lawyers, trade unions and Hollywood.

headline.main: Corporate Donors Now Big Backers Of the Democrats

docs.abstract: Democratic Party has aggressively courted business support, and now counts large corporations among its biggest donors; they will be well represented at seven-figure fund-raising events during party's national convention; formerly, Democratic National Committee relied heavily on triad of financial support: trial lawyers, trade unions and Hollywood; in last 18 months, Democratic National Committee has collected $118.6 million in soft-money donations, unregulated gifts from unions, corporations and wealthy individuals, nearly erasing traditional Republican advantage in such contributions; Republicans reported $137 million in soft-money donations over same period; unions are 6 of Democratic Party's 10 top donors, but bulk of party's money is coming from corporations and individuals who are motivated by ideology or impulse to put down marker on what might be winning ticket; chart (M)

byline.original: By JOHN M. BRODER and RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton's assertion that she played a quiet but major role in several policy and legislative efforts by the Clinton administration cannot be trusted and stems from a bid to ''reinvent'' herself for voters, Representative Rick A. Lazio said yesterday. ''My sense is this is just another attempt to reinvent Hillary Clinton and that is why the people of New York have such a problem with credibility when it comes to the Clinton campaign,'' Mr. Lazio, who is running against Mrs. Clinton for a United States Senate seat from New York, said in an interview yesterday after returning from a cross-country fund-raising tour.

headline.main: Lazio Disputes Mrs. Clinton On Quiet Accomplishments

docs.abstract: Rick Lazio disputes Hillary Clinton's assertion that she has played quiet but major role in Clinton administration's policy initiatives, interview after cross-country tour to raise money for New York Senate race (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 Canada Moving to Guard Integrity of Its Diamonds Canadian officials, acting to protect their country's emerging diamond industry, are taking steps to ensure that their stones are never confused with the ''blood diamonds'' that help to finance guerrilla armies in Sierra Leone and Angola. For instance, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police are developing a technology to ''fingerprint'' diamonds, identifying them by trace impurities that could be traced to known mines. A1 Argentine Beef Trade Halted The United States has temporarily halted trade in Argentine beef because of concerns of a possible outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease in Argentina. A6 Concordes Stay on the Ground France's transportation minister reiterated that Air France's five remaining Concordes would remain grounded for the time being because of continuing uncertainty about why the supersonic jet caught fire last month and crashed north of Paris. A4 Effort on Behalf of Pinochet Gen. Augusto Pinochet and his backers have started a campaign to gain public support in helping him avert a trial on charges of kidnapping, murder and torture. An estimated 30 percent of the country still considers the former dictator a hero. A6 Prague Prepares for I.M.F. Czech officials and private businesses are taking measures to guard against the possibility of violent protests accompanying a meeting of the International Monetary Fund next month. A3 U.N. Refugee Official Leaving Sadako Ogata, the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, plans to retire at the end of the year, and the search is on to find a replacement within the next month or two. A5 Tourism Grows in Belfast Two neighborhoods in Belfast that were the center of the sectarian violence that held the city hostage for the last 30 years have become a tourist attraction, thanks to murals created by members of both sides of the ''troubles.'' A4 World Briefing A4 NATIONAL A8-13, 16 U.S. to Forgo Hearings On EgyptAir 990 Crash The government's top air safey investigator said there were no safety issues that would require a public hearing into the crash of EgyptAir Flight 990 last fall, and he disclosed information that reinforced suspicion that a co-pilot deliberately plunged the plane into the Atlantic Ocean off Nantucket, killing all 217 people aboard. The information included F.B.I. reports showing that the co-pilot, Gamil al-Batouti, had been accused of various sexual improprieties at a Manhattan hotel in the year before the crash. A1 Study of Food-Stamp Process A national network of food banks and advocacy groups said food-stamp applications in most states had become so onerous that needy people were deterred from seeking help. A1 Assessing Blame for Wildfires Conservative critics -- including the Republican governor of Montana -- said the Clinton administration did not move fast enough to ward off the wildfires burning large chunks of the West. Federal officials and their supporters rejected the accusations. A8 Cheney's Golden Parachute Halliburton was said to have agreed to give Dick Cheney a retirement package worth about $20 million. Mr. Cheney, who joined the energy services company in 1995, quit as chairman and chief executive last month to join the Republican ticket. A1 Bush Challenges Gore Gov. George W. Bush called on Vice President Al Gore to emphatically state his disapproval of President Clinton's sexual conduct in office and to send a clear message that he would maintain a high level of integrity if elected president. A11 Playboy Event Is Moved Representative Loretta Sanchez, bowing to pressure from Democratic Party officials, agreed to move a fund-raiser from the Playboy mansion to Universal Studios. A11 Buchanan Names Black Woman Patrick J. Buchanan, nominated for president by one faction of the Reform Party, selected as his running mate Ezola Foster, a black woman who taught public school for years in South Central Los Angeles. The party's other faction nominated John Hagelin for president, touching off a fight over who is entitled to $12.6 million in federal campaign funds. A10 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Police Retirements Surge; Discontent Cited as Factor More than 700 police officers have filed for retirement this year, a 38 percent increase over the same seven-month period last year. Department officials say that is a trickle in a department with 40,000 officers, but union leaders say it is the start of a major exodus, as officers seek better-paying, less dangerous jobs where no one calls them names. A1 Doctor Barred From Practicing The State Department of Health suspended the medical license of Dr. Niels H. Lauersen, a well-known fertility specialist with a busy, celebrity-favored practice; he is facing retrial on insurance fraud charges. B1 A Campaign Stop on 'Tonight' Hillary Rodham Clinton and Jay Leno bantered gently during her appearance on ''The Tonight Show,'' but she also sought to steer the conversation toward serious subjects integral to her Senate campaign. Mrs. Clinton's three-day campaign and fund-raising schedule will be capped with a prime-time speech to the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles on Monday. B1 Representative Rick A. Lazio scoffed at Mrs. Clinton's assertion that she played a quiet but major role in Clinton administration policy and legislative efforts. B4 Trade Center Elevator Accident Twelve people were trapped for an hour between the 78th and 79th floors of the World Trade Center after their elevator overshot a floor, hit a ceiling and dropped 15 feet. Injuries included cuts and broken bones. B2 Assault May Be One of Several A man who sustained head injuries on Thursday in an assault in his Upper West Side apartment may have been attacked by the same person responsible for the burglaries of seven other residences in the area, including several incidents that ended in violence, the police said. B3 Beliefs B6 OBITUARIES C16 SPORTS D1-8 Yanks Hanging On to Clemens Roger Clemens (9-6) is set to sign a contract extension worth $30.9 million over three years. D1 BUSINESS DAY C1-14 Rate Rise in Japan The central bank raised interest rates for the first time in a decade, to 0.25 percent for the benchmark overnight call rate, despite pressure from government officials to keep borrowing costs close to zero. C1 G.M. Looking to Sell Online G.M. is proposing a joint venture with its dealers to establish a Web site offering its own cars -- and those of other makers -- for sale. C1 Dow Back Above 11,000 The Dow rose 119.04 points, or 1.1 percent, to 11,027.80, its first close above 11,000 since April. The S.& P. 500 gained 11.59 points, to 1,471.84, and the Nasdaq climbed 29.48 points, to 3,789.47. C3 A Billionaire Recants George Soros, one of the world's most successful speculators and richest men, says in a new book that he was wrong to write in 1998 of the imminent ''disintegration of the global capitalist system.'' C1 Murdoch Seeks Chris-Craft The News Corporation, controlled by Rupert Murdoch, was said to have agreed to acquire Chris-Craft Industries, a television station company, for $3.5 billion. Chris-Craft owns 10 stations, while the News Corporation, which owns the Fox network, has 22 stations. C2 Business Digest C1 ARTS & IDEAS B7-16 EDITORIAL A14-15 Editorials: Time for a convention update; Germany's immigration debate; a rescue plan for Camden. Columns: Frank Rich, Anthony Lewis. Bridge B12 TV Listings B16 Crossword B13 Weather C15 Public Lives A8

docs.lead_paragraph: The New York State Department of Health yesterday suspended the medical license of a well-known fertility specialist with a busy, celebrity-favored practice who is facing retrial on insurance fraud charges. The state health commissioner, Dr. Antonia C. Novello, deciding the doctor posed ''an imminent danger to public health,'' used her emergency powers to suspend the license of Dr. Niels H. Lauersen before a state investigative committee had finished reviewing the cases brought against him.

headline.main: Fertility Doctor Loses License During Review

docs.lead_paragraph: It could have been one of those minor triumphs that make a phone rep's day: Dawn Barbour, a customer service agent for Verizon -- then Bell Atlantic -- had just made an angry customer stop ranting, solved his problem and even elicited a kind word. ''I hate Bell Atlantic, but you're the nicest rep I ever had,'' the caller said.

headline.main: When 'May I Help You' Is a Labor Issue; The Customer-Service Assembly Line

docs.abstract: Striking Verizon Communications customer service employees, represented by Communications Workers of America, claim on-the-job stress stemming from scripted phrases they are obligated to recite to customers and from supervisory monitoring of their phone calls for 'quality assurance'; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A bomb apparently targeted at foreigners went off at a Dusseldorf train station recently, injuring nine immigrants, six of them Jews, as they returned home from a German-language class. A few days later, with great fanfare, a 25-year-old Indonesian software specialist became the first recipient of a new visa Germany plans to give to foreigners with computer skills. The juxtaposition underscored one of the main challenges facing German society and Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's government -- the nation's need to be more welcoming to immigrants. The Dusseldorf bombing, along with a rash of other attacks on foreigners, has provoked much soul-searching. Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer of the Green Party urged Germans to speak out against skinhead and neo-Nazi violence, lest the perpetrators believe they are acting on behalf of a silent majority.
docs.abstract: Editorial on recent attacks against foreigners in Germany holds that one of main challenges facing German society and Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's government is nation's need to be more welcoming to immigrants
